issue.title: fix for failing time series tests due to pmdarima 2.0.0

labels.description: Topics related to the time series

repository.name: pycaret

issue.body:
## Related Issue or bug

Tests are failing due to the new release for pmdarima 2.0.0.

Related:  
- https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3300
- https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3301
- https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3302

#### Describe the changes you've made

Pinned pmdarima temporarily to not use 2.0.0. Will need to remove this once fixed in sktime.

## Type of change

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)
- [ ] This change requires a documentation update

## How Has This Been Tested?

Existing unit tests should pass on GitHub

## Checklist:

- [x] My code follows the style guidelines of this project.
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my own code.
- [ ] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas.
- [ ] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation.
- [x] My changes generate no new warnings.
- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works.
- [x] New and existing unit tests pass locally with my changes.
- [ ] Any dependent changes have been merged and published in downstream modules.

body:
This breaks method `predict` for ARIMA. 

```python
forecaster = AutoARIMA()
forecaster.fit(data)
forecast = forecaster.predict(fh=[1])
# KeyError: "None of [Int64Index([0], dtype='int64')] are in the [index]"
```

Running `pip install -U pmdarima==1.8.5 sktime==0.13.0` fixes the problem. 

Is it possible to fix dependency version for future releases? Unfortunately, this impacted code in production and would delay results for two weeks

@ciberger, @ngupta23, this relates to an old discussion here:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1480

There are two opposing poles in the discussion:
* we should not have defensive version bounds, since that is not nice for reverse dependencies and, if everyone does this, it might ultimately lead to unsatisfiable constraint combinations
* we should have defensive version bounds and bump them every release, because otherwise it can break user code that does not itself have defensive version bounds

I'm not sure where the discussion was had since the issue #1480 only has my posts, but I remember a notably heated discussion  (@aiwalter, @lmmentel, @freddyaboulton, where is all th discussion?), and the current majority opinion among core developers is "we should not have defensive version bounds and should gradually remove the ones in place"

Perhaps we can find a compromise and put defensive version founds for MAJOR but not MINOR releases?
Either way, the 0.13.2 release will have the pmdarima bound in.
can someone paste the exception message here? @ciberger what is "data" in your case? Would be good to provide a reproducible code

but this seems unrelated to `pmdarima` version?

I suspect the issue appears on the `fh` parameter from `predict`. Defined as list or with `ForecastingHorizon` triggers the error.

Here you have the error message. 
```python
/local_disk0/.ephemeral_nfs/envs/pythonEnv-958c1258-3728-45b7-bb5a-105442b141b8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_fh.py:100: FutureWarning: pandas.Int64Index is deprecated and will be removed from pandas in a future version. Use pandas.Index with the appropriate dtype instead.
  values = pd.Int64Index(values, dtype=int)
Out[27]: ForecastingHorizon([1], dtype='int64', is_relative=True)
```

I highly thought this is generated due an index issue in the input data.
I can just see a warning, please share full trace

@ciberger are you getting any deprecation warning on the last old version that is working if you set `suppress_warnings=False`? If not, we should complain at `pmdarima` about it. In future, we can avoid such issues if we have a CI/CD pipeline step that checks for deprecation warnings so we can see them before the actual deprecation is happening
